module.title: Frontend Frameworks
module.description: Explore React, Vue, Svelte, Angular and choose the right framework

lessons.title: Framework vs Library
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - Library = you call its functions (React) - Framework = it calls your code (Angular) - Frameworks are opinionated, libraries are flexible - Both help build complex UIs faster --- # Framework vs Library: What's the Difference? ## The Key Difference **Library:** You are in control ```javascript // You import and use it when YOU want import { render } from 'my-library'; function myApp() { render(
Hello
); } ``` **Framework:** It is in control ```javascript // Framework calls YOUR code // You follow its structure export class AppComponent { // Framework calls this automatically ngOnInit() { // Your code here } } ``` ## The Hollywood Principle **"Don't call us, we'll call you"** **Library:** You call the library **Framework:** The framework calls you ## Real Examples **React (Library):** ```jsx import React from 'react'; import ReactDOM from 'react-dom'; // You decide when and how to use it function App() { return

Hello

; } ReactDOM.render(, document.getElementById('root')); ``` You can use React anywhere, anyway you want! **Angular (Framework):** ```typescript import { Component } from '@angular/core'; // Must follow Angular's structure @Component({ selector: 'app-root', template: '

Hello

' }) export class AppComponent { // Angular calls your lifecycle methods } ``` Angular dictates the structure! ## Framework Characteristics **Opinionated:** - âœ… "Do it this way" - âœ… Built-in routing - âœ… Built-in state management - âœ… Specific file structure - âŒ Less flexibility **Examples:** Angular, Ember, Vue (more opinionated) ## Library Characteristics **Flexible:** - âœ… "Do it your way" - âœ… Pick your own tools - âœ… Use only what you need - âŒ More decisions to make - âŒ Need to integrate tools yourself **Examples:** React, Preact, Vue (can be library-like) ## Metaphor: Building a House **Library = Tools:** - You buy a hammer, saw, drill - You decide how to build the house - More freedom, more decisions - Can build anything **Framework = Kit Home:** - Comes with blueprints - "Put wall A here, roof B there" - Faster to build (if you follow the plan) - Limited to the design ## Spectrum: Library â†’ Framework ``` More Flexible â†â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â†’ More Opinionated React Vue Svelte Angular Ember (Library) (Both) (Library) (Framework) (Framework) ``` ## When to Use a Framework **Choose framework when:** - âœ… You want structure - âœ… Large team needs consistency - âœ… You want built-in features - âœ… You're new and want guidance - âœ… Enterprise application ## When to Use a Library **Choose library when:** - âœ… You want flexibility - âœ… Need to integrate with existing code - âœ… Want to pick your own tools - âœ… Building something unique - âœ… Smaller project ## Modern Trend: Hybrid Many modern tools blur the line: **Next.js:** - Built on React (library) - But provides framework-like structure - Best of both worlds? **Vue:** - Can be used as library (CDN script) - Can be used as framework (Vue CLI, structure) ## The Bottom Line **Library:** "Here are tools, you build" **Framework:** "Here's the blueprint, you fill in details" Both are valid! Choose based on: - Team size - Project complexity - Your preference - Time constraints

lessons.title: React Ecosystem
Vue: Progressive Framework
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - Vue is progressive (start simple, add features as needed) - Template-based syntax (feels like HTML) - Easier learning curve than React - Built-in state management and routing options --- # Vue: The Progressive Framework ## What is Vue? **Vue** is a progressive JavaScript framework for building UIs. **"Progressive" means:** Start simple, add complexity only when needed! **Level 1: Just a script tag** ```html
{{ message }}
``` **Level 2: Single File Components** ```vue ``` **Level 3: Full framework with router, state management, etc.** ## Why Developers Love Vue **1. Template Syntax (feels natural)** ```vue ``` Looks like HTML! **2. Reactive Data** ```vue ``` **3. Built-in Directives** ```vue ``` **4. Composition API (modern)** ```vue ``` ## Single File Components (.vue) ```vue ``` Template, logic, and styles in one file! ## Vue Ecosystem **Official libraries (well-integrated):** **Vue Router:** ```javascript import { createRouter, createWebHistory } from 'vue-router'; const router = createRouter({ history: createWebHistory(), routes: [ { path: '/', component: Home }, { path: '/about', component: About } ] }); ``` **Pinia (state management):** ```javascript import { defineStore } from 'pinia'; export const useUserStore = defineStore('user', { state: () => ({ name: 'Alice', age: 25 }), actions: { updateName(newName) { this.name = newName; } } }); ``` **Nuxt.js (meta-framework):** Vue's equivalent to Next.js ## Vue vs React **Vue:** - âœ… Easier to learn - âœ… Template-based (familiar) - âœ… Built-in solutions - âœ… Better documentation - âŒ Smaller ecosystem - âŒ Fewer jobs **React:** - âœ… Larger ecosystem - âœ… More jobs - âœ… More flexible - âŒ Steeper learning curve - âŒ Need to choose libraries ## When to Choose Vue **Great for:** - âœ… Beginners learning frontend frameworks - âœ… Teams that want productivity - âœ… Progressive enhancement (start simple) - âœ… When you want official solutions - âœ… Smaller to medium projects ## Pros & Cons **âœ… Pros:** - Easy to learn - Great documentation - Template syntax is intuitive - Official router and state management - Single File Components - Progressive (flexible) **âŒ Cons:** - Smaller community than React - Fewer jobs - Less corporate backing - Smaller ecosystem

lessons.title: Svelte: The Compiled Framework
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - Svelte compiles to vanilla JavaScript (no runtime) - Write less code than React or Vue - Truly reactive (no virtual DOM) - Smaller bundle sizes --- # Svelte: Rethinking Reactivity ## What Makes Svelte Different? **Svelte is a compiler, not a framework!** **Traditional frameworks (React, Vue):** ``` Your code â†’ Browser â†’ Framework runs â†’ Updates DOM â†‘ Framework overhead ``` **Svelte:** ``` Your code â†’ Compiler â†’ Vanilla JavaScript â†’ Browser â†’ Updates DOM â†‘ No framework! ``` ## Why This Matters **1. Smaller bundles** - No framework to ship - Only your code (compiled) **2. Faster runtime** - No virtual DOM - Direct DOM updates **3. Less code to write** - No boilerplate - Built-in reactivity ## Svelte Syntax **Component:** ```svelte ``` No `useState`, no `this.setState` - just variables! ## Reactive Declarations ```svelte

Count: {count}

Doubled: {doubled}

``` The `$:` syntax marks reactive code! ## Props & Events **Parent:** ```svelte ``` **Child:** ```svelte

Hello {name}

``` ## Stores (State Management) **Writable store:** ```javascript // stores.js import { writable } from 'svelte/store'; export const count = writable(0); ``` **Using in component:** ```svelte

Count: {$count}

``` The `$` prefix auto-subscribes! ## Conditional & Loops ```svelte {#if user.loggedIn}

Welcome, {user.name}!

{:else}

Please log in

{/if}
    {#each items as item, index}
  • {index + 1}. {item}
    • {/each}
``` ## Animations Built-in ```svelte {#if visible}
I fade in and out!
{/if} ``` Animations with one line! ## SvelteKit (Meta-Framework) **Svelte's equivalent to Next.js:** - File-based routing - SSR, SSG, CSR - API routes - Built on Vite (fast!) ```javascript // src/routes/+page.svelte

Home page

// src/routes/about/+page.svelte

About page

// Automatically routed! ``` ## Pros & Cons **âœ… Pros:** - Write less code - Smaller bundles - Faster runtime - Built-in animations - Great DX (developer experience) - Easy to learn **âŒ Cons:** - Smaller ecosystem - Fewer jobs - Less mature - Fewer third-party libraries - Smaller community ## When to Choose Svelte **Great for:** - âœ… New projects - âœ… Performance-critical apps - âœ… Smaller bundle size matters - âœ… You want to write less code - âœ… Embedded widgets **Maybe not for:** - âŒ When you need lots of libraries - âŒ Large enterprise teams - âŒ When you need many developers

lessons.title: Angular: Full Framework
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - Angular is a full framework by Google - TypeScript required (built-in) - Opinionated with everything included - Great for large enterprise applications --- # Angular: The Enterprise Choice ## What is Angular? **Angular** is a complete framework with everything built-in: - Component system - Routing - HTTP client - Forms - Dependency injection - Testing tools - CLI **Everything you need, out of the box!** ## Why Angular is Different **React approach (library):** ``` React â†’ You choose: - Router? (React Router, TanStack Router) - State? (Redux, Zustand) - Forms? (React Hook Form, Formik) - HTTP? (fetch, axios) ``` **Angular approach (framework):** ``` Angular â†’ Everything included: âœ… Router (Angular Router) âœ… State (RxJS, Services) âœ… Forms (Angular Forms) âœ… HTTP (HttpClient) ``` No choices needed - use what's provided! ## Angular Component ```typescript import { Component } from '@angular/core'; @Component({ selector: 'app-counter', template: `

Count: {{ count }}

`, styles: [` div { padding: 20px; } button { background: blue; color: white; } `] }) export class CounterComponent { count = 0; increment() { this.count++; } } ``` **Key features:** - Decorators (`@Component`) - Template syntax - TypeScript classes ## Dependency Injection **Service:** ```typescript import { Injectable } from '@angular/core'; import { HttpClient } from '@angular/common/http'; @Injectable({ providedIn: 'root' }) export class UserService { constructor(private http: HttpClient) {} getUsers() { return this.http.get('/api/users'); } } ``` **Component using service:** ```typescript import { Component, OnInit } from '@angular/core'; import { UserService } from './user.service'; @Component({ selector: 'app-users', template: `
{{ user.name }}
` }) export class UsersComponent implements OnInit { users = []; // Service injected automatically! constructor(private userService: UserService) {} ngOnInit() { this.userService.getUsers().subscribe( data => this.users = data ); } } ``` ## Template Syntax **Interpolation:** ```html

{{ title }}

{{ 1 + 1 }}

``` **Property binding:** ```html ``` **Event binding:** ```html ``` **Two-way binding:** ```html

Hello {{ name }}

``` **Directives:** ```html
Welcome!
  • {{ i }}. {{ item }}

    • Loading...

    Error!

    Content

    ``` ## RxJS & Observables Angular uses **RxJS** for reactive programming: ```typescript import { Observable } from 'rxjs'; import { map, filter } from 'rxjs/operators'; export class DataComponent { users$: Observable; constructor(private http: HttpClient) { this.users$ = this.http.get('/api/users').pipe( map(users => users.filter(u => u.active)), map(users => users.slice(0, 10)) ); } } ``` ```html
    {{ user.name }}
    ``` ## Angular CLI **Powerful command-line tool:** ```bash # Create new project ng new my-app # Generate component ng generate component user-profile # or: ng g c user-profile # Generate service ng generate service user # Serve app ng serve # Build for production ng build --prod # Run tests ng test ``` ## Modules **Angular uses NgModules:** ```typescript import { NgModule } from '@angular/core'; import { BrowserModule } from '@angular/platform-browser'; import { AppComponent } from './app.component'; @NgModule({ declarations: [AppComponent], // Components imports: [BrowserModule], // Other modules providers: [], // Services bootstrap: [AppComponent] // Root component }) export class AppModule {} ``` ## Pros & Cons **âœ… Pros:** - Everything included - TypeScript by default - Great for large teams - Opinionated (consistency) - Backed by Google - Powerful CLI - Excellent for enterprise **âŒ Cons:** - Steep learning curve - Verbose - Heavy framework - Less flexible - Smaller community than React - RxJS complexity ## When to Choose Angular **Great for:** - âœ… Large enterprise applications - âœ… Teams that need structure - âœ… Long-term projects - âœ… When you want everything built-in - âœ… TypeScript projects **Maybe not for:** - âŒ Small projects - âŒ Prototypes - âŒ When you want flexibility - âŒ When bundle size matters

lessons.title: Comparison and Choosing
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- No "best" framework - depends on your needs
- Consider: team size, project scope, timeline, ecosystem
- React has most jobs, Vue easiest to learn, Angular best for enterprise
- You can't go wrong with any of them

---

# Choosing the Right Framework

## Quick Comparison

**React:**
- ğŸ“š Library, not framework
- âš›ï¸ JSX syntax
- ğŸ”§ Bring your own tools
- ğŸ‘¥ Huge ecosystem
- ğŸ’¼ Most jobs

**Vue:**
- ğŸŒ± Progressive framework
- ğŸ“ Template-based
- ğŸ Official solutions included
- ğŸ“ Easiest to learn
- ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³ Popular in Asia

**Svelte:**
- âš¡ Compiler (no runtime)
- ğŸ“¦ Smallest bundles
- âœï¸ Write less code
- ğŸ†• Newest/modern
- ğŸŒŸ Best DX

**Angular:**
- ğŸ¢ Full framework
- ğŸ“˜ TypeScript required
- ğŸ¯ Opinionated
- ğŸ—ï¸ Everything built-in
- ğŸ’¼ Enterprise favorite

## Bundle Size Comparison

**"Hello World" app (gzipped):**
- Svelte: ~2 KB
- Vue: ~10 KB
- React: ~40 KB
- Angular: ~60 KB

**Note:** Real apps differ, but Svelte is consistently smaller!

## Learning Curve

```
Easy â†â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â†’ Hard

Vue < Svelte < React < Angular
```

**Vue:** Feels like HTML, easy to start
**Svelte:** Simple syntax, but new concepts
**React:** JSX and hooks take time
**Angular:** TypeScript, RxJS, concepts

## Job Market (2024)

**Based on job postings:**

1. **React** - 60%
2. **Angular** - 20%
3. **Vue** - 15%
4. **Svelte** - 5%

React dominates, but all have opportunities!

## Decision Matrix

### Choose React if:
- âœ… You want maximum job opportunities
- âœ… You need a huge ecosystem
- âœ… You value flexibility
- âœ… You're building SPAs
- âœ… You're okay learning curve

### Choose Vue if:
- âœ… You're new to frameworks
- âœ… You want great documentation
- âœ… You like template syntax
- âœ… You want official solutions
- âœ… You're building in Asia

### Choose Svelte if:
- âœ… Performance is critical
- âœ… Bundle size matters
- âœ… You want to write less code
- âœ… You're building new projects
- âœ… You value developer experience

### Choose Angular if:
- âœ… Building enterprise apps
- âœ… Large team needs structure
- âœ… You love TypeScript
- âœ… You want everything included
- âœ… Long-term maintenance

## By Project Type

**Small Personal Project:**
â†’ Svelte or Vue (quick, easy)

**Startup MVP:**
â†’ React or Vue (fast development, hiring)

**Enterprise Application:**
â†’ Angular or React (mature, supported)

**Performance-Critical:**
â†’ Svelte (smallest, fastest)

**Large Team:**
â†’ Angular (structure) or React (talent pool)

**Embedded Widget:**
â†’ Svelte or Preact (tiny bundle)

## Ecosystem Comparison

**React:**
- Router: React Router, TanStack Router
- State: Redux, Zustand, Jotai, Recoil
- Forms: React Hook Form, Formik
- Data: React Query, SWR
- Meta: Next.js, Remix, Gatsby

**Vue:**
- Router: Vue Router (official)
- State: Pinia (official)
- Forms: VeeValidate
- Data: VueUse
- Meta: Nuxt.js

**Svelte:**
- Router: SvelteKit (official)
- State: Svelte stores (built-in)
- Forms: Built-in
- Data: Fetch API
- Meta: SvelteKit

**Angular:**
- Router: Angular Router (built-in)
- State: RxJS, NgRx
- Forms: Angular Forms (built-in)
- Data: HttpClient (built-in)
- Meta: Angular Universal

## Performance

**Initial Load:**
Svelte > Vue > React > Angular

**Runtime:**
Svelte â‰ˆ Vue > React > Angular

**Memory:**
Svelte < Vue < React < Angular

**Note:** For most apps, the difference is negligible!

## Can't Decide?

**Start with React if:**
- You want to maximize career options
- You need maximum flexibility

**Start with Vue if:**
- You're learning your first framework
- You want to be productive quickly

**Start with Svelte if:**
- You love trying modern tech
- You prioritize DX and performance

**Start with Angular if:**
- You're building enterprise software
- Your team/company already uses it

## The Truth

**All of these frameworks are excellent!**

- They all solve the same problems
- They all have pros and cons
- They all can build great apps
- Learning one helps you learn others

**The best framework is the one that:**
- Your team knows
- Fits your project
- You enjoy using

## Final Advice

**Don't overthink it!**

1. Pick one based on your situation
2. Learn it well
3. Build projects
4. Learn another if curious

The skills transfer between frameworks!

exercises.title: Framework or Library?
exercises.description: Identify whether each statement describes a framework or library.

questions.question: Which is a characteristic of a FRAMEWORK?
options: You call its functions when needed
It calls your code following its structure
questions.explanation: Frameworks follow the 'Hollywood Principle' - they call your code. You work within their structure.

questions.question: React is considered a:
questions.explanation: React is a library - you import and use it when you want, you're in control of the app structure.

questions.question: Which is true about opinionated frameworks?
questions.explanation: Opinionated frameworks provide structure and built-in solutions, reducing choice but increasing consistency.

questions.question: When should you choose a framework over a library?
options: When you want to pick your own tools
When you want structure and consistency
questions.explanation: Frameworks are great when you want structure, consistency, and don't want to make many decisions.

exercises.title: React Knowledge Check
exercises.description: Test your understanding of React concepts.

questions.question: What is JSX?
questions.explanation: JSX is a syntax extension that lets you write HTML-like code in JavaScript files.

questions.question: Which hook manages component state in React?
questions.explanation: useState is the hook for managing local component state in React.

questions.question: What's a key drawback of React compared to frameworks like Angular?
options: Need to choose your own routing/state libraries
questions.explanation: React is just a UI library, so you need to choose additional libraries for routing, state management, etc.

questions.question: Which is NOT part of React itself?
questions.explanation: React Router is a separate library. React only provides the core UI functionality.

questions.question: When should you use React?
options: For dynamic, interactive UIs and SPAs
questions.explanation: React excels at building dynamic, interactive user interfaces and single-page applications.

questions.question: What does 'progressive' mean for Vue?
options: Start simple, add features as needed
questions.explanation: Progressive means you can start with a simple script tag and gradually adopt more features as needed.

questions.question: What syntax does Vue use for templates?
questions.explanation: Vue uses HTML-like template syntax that feels familiar and natural.

questions.question: Compared to React, Vue is generally:
questions.explanation: Vue is generally considered easier to learn because of its template syntax and clearer documentation.

questions.question: What does v-model do in Vue?
questions.explanation: v-model creates two-way data binding between form inputs and component data.

questions.question: How is Svelte fundamentally different from React/Vue?
options: It compiles to vanilla JS (no runtime)
questions.explanation: Svelte is a compiler that produces vanilla JavaScript, unlike React/Vue which run in the browser.

questions.question: What does the $ prefix mean in Svelte?
options: Auto-subscribe to stores or reactive declarations
questions.explanation: In Svelte, $ is used for reactive declarations ($: statement) and auto-subscribing to stores ($store).

questions.question: Main advantage of Svelte's compiler approach?
options: Smaller bundle size and no runtime overhead
questions.explanation: Compiling to vanilla JS means smaller bundles and no framework runtime overhead.

questions.question: How do you make a variable reactive in Svelte?
questions.explanation: In Svelte, regular variable declarations are automatically reactive. Just use let!

exercises.title: Choosing Your Framework
exercises.description: Make the right framework choice for different scenarios.

questions.question: You're building a large enterprise app with a 20-person team. Which framework?
questions.explanation: Angular's opinionated structure, built-in features, and TypeScript make it ideal for large enterprise teams.

questions.question: You're a beginner learning your first framework. Which should you start with?
questions.explanation: Vue has the easiest learning curve with great documentation and familiar template syntax.

questions.question: You need maximum job opportunities. Which has the most jobs?
questions.explanation: React dominates the job market with about 60% of frontend framework positions.

questions.question: You're building a performance-critical embedded widget. Which framework?
questions.explanation: Svelte produces the smallest bundles and has no runtime, perfect for embedded widgets.

questions.question: What's the truth about choosing a framework?
options: All are excellent, choose based on your needs
questions.explanation: All modern frameworks are excellent. Choose based on your specific project needs, team, and preferences.
